column2: known as Gabriel Jesus (Brazilian Portuguese: [ɡabɾiˈɛw ʒeˈzus])
column3: is a Brazilian professional footballer who plays as a forward for Premier League club Manchester City and the Brazil national team.

column1: Jesus began his career at Palmeiras. He was voted the best newcomer of the 2015 Campeonato Brasileiro Série A
column2: a year in which he also helped his team win the Copa do Brasil. The following year he was named the player of the season as Palmeiras won their first national league title in 22 years. He joined Manchester City in January 2017 for a transfer fee of €32 million
column3: and won the Premier League in 2018 and 2019

column1: After winning 21 caps and scoring seven goals at youth level
column2: including reaching the final of the 2015 FIFA U-20 World Cup and winning an Olympic gold medal at the 2016 Summer Olympics
column3: Jesus made his senior debut for Brazil in September 2016
column4: and was part of the squad that took part at the 2018 FIFA World Cup
column5: later also winning the 2019 Copa América.

column2: Jesus grew up in the neighborhood of Jardim Peri. After initially playing street football
column3: he joined amateur clubs in the region
column4: his last one being Associação Atlética Anhanguera.

column2: Jesus signed a youth contract with Palmeiras. He was also the club's top goalscorer during the year

column3: Jesus signed a three-year contract for Palmeiras with an additional two
column4: with his salary to increase from R$15
column5: 000 to four times as much in the fifth year; the fee to buy him out from his contract increased tenfold to R$30 million. However
column6: the deal changed the balance of his economic rights from 75–25% in favour of Palmeiras
column7: to 70–30% in favour of his agents.Jesus scored 37 goals in 22 games for Palmeiras in the 2014 edition of the state under-17 championship
column8: leading to offers from clubs throughout the country and abroad. He was first included in Palmeiras' squad for a senior match on 27 August 2014
column9: remaining an unused substitute as they lost 0–1 at home to Clube Atlético Mineiro in the first leg of the last 16 of the year's Copa do Brasil. He did not make any senior appearances during the campaign
column10: as his side was seriously threatened with relegation; this decision
column11: took by managers Ricardo Gareca and Dorival Júnior
column12: was widely criticized by the supporters
column13: who demanded a change for the youngster through a petition.

column1: Jesus made his senior debut on 7 March 2015 in the season's Campeonato Paulista
column2: replacing Leandro Pereira in the 73rd minute of a 1–0 win over CA Bragantino at Allianz Parque. He totalled eight appearances
column4: as the Verdão lost on a penalty shootout in the final against Santos.

column1: Jesus made his first career start on 29 April in the second leg of the second round of the year's cup
column2: a 1–1 draw at Sampaio Corrêa Futebol Clube (6–2 aggregate). On 9 May
column3: he made his first appearance in the Campeonato Brasileiro Série A
column4: starting in a 2–2 home draw against Atlético Mineiro on the first day of the season.Jesus' first professional goal came in the next round of the cup
column5: away to Agremiação Sportiva Arapiraquense on 15 July
column6: the only goal of the two-legged tie. On 26 August
column7: his two first-half strikes at the Estádio Governador Magalhães Pinto gave Palmeiras a 3–2 win over Cruzeiro Esporte Clube (5–3 aggregate)
column8: putting them into the quarter-finals. Four days later he got his first league goals
column9: starting and finishing a 3–2 win over Joinville Esporte Clube; the first goal came after 52 seconds.Jesus finished the campaign with four goals from 20 games
column10: and his team defeated Santos to win the cup; he was also a starter in both legs of the finals
column11: but being substituted before half-time due to a shoulder injury. He was elected Best Newcomer in the league.On 4 February 2016
column12: Jesus scored his first Paulista goal
column13: opening a 2–2 home draw with Esporte Clube São Bento in the second game of the season. Twelve days later
column14: he scored his first goal in continental football
column15: a 2–2 draw away to Uruguay's River Plate in the opening game of the group stage of the year's Copa Libertadores
column16: after coming on at the interval in place of fellow youngster Erik Lima. Away to Rosario Central on 6 April
column17: he scored twice in a 3–3 draw but was sent off for the first time in his career for fighting with Damián Musto; he later apologised for his misconduct.In the opening game of the national season at home to Clube Atlético Paranaense on 14 May
column18: Jesus scored twice in the second half of a 4–0 win. He scored 12 goals as the team won their first national championship since 1994
column19: and was named Bola de Ouro for player of the season.

column2: it was announced that Jesus would sign for Premier League club Manchester City in January 2017 on a contract until the summer of 2021. City paid a reported fee of £27 million/€33 million
column3: plus add-ons. The transfer was fully completed on 19 January 2017.

column1: Jesus made his first Premier League appearance on 21 January
column2: coming on as an 82nd-minute substitute for Raheem Sterling in a 2–2 draw with Tottenham Hotspur at the City of Manchester Stadium. A week later
column3: Jesus made his first appearance in Manchester City's starting XI
column4: assisting a goal for Sterling in a 3–0 FA Cup win over Crystal Palace. On 1 February he made his first Premier League start in place of Sergio Agüero
column5: and assisted Kevin De Bruyne in the 17th minute and then scored his first goal for the club in the 39th. With this
column6: he became the first Manchester City player to have a goal and an assist in their first Premier League start
column7: as well as only the third City player to be involved in two or more goals in their first Premier League start. In his fourth game (third league start) Jesus broke a metatarsal in his right foot and was expected to be out for the remainder of the 2016–17 Premier League season. However
column8: he returned in April for the Manchester Derby
column9: coming on as a substitute in a goalless draw. Jesus ended the 2016–17 season with 7 goals and 4 assists in 11 games.He scored his first Premier League goal of the 2017–18 season on 26 August
column10: an equaliser in a 2–1 away win over AFC Bournemouth
column11: and added two more in a 5–0 win against Liverpool on 9 September. He had a 14-game goal drought between 18 November 2017 and 7 March 2018 that encompassed a knee medial ligament injury on New Year's Eve
column12: and after breaking his duck in the Champions League loss to FC Basel he admitted that fear of getting injured was affecting his game. Jesus scored the last Premier League goal in the 2017–18 season against Southampton in the 94th minute
column13: to secure City a league record 100 points. On 3 August 2018
column14: Jesus signed a contract extension with Manchester City

column2: Gabriel Jesus scored 4 goals for the first time in his career against Burton Albion in a 9–0 victory.On 13 March 2019
column3: Jesus scored once after coming on for Sergio Agüero in the 7–0 (10–2 aggregate) UEFA Champions League Round of 16 win over Schalke 04 and in doing so helped the club equal the record for the largest winning margin in the knockout-phase of the competition.On 22 June 2019
column4: Jesus switched his jersey number from the number '33' shirt to the number '9' shirt.On 7 August 2020
column5: Jesus assisted and scored both goals respectively in a 2–1 win in the second leg of the round of 16 of the Champions League against Real Madrid
column6: played at the Etihad Stadium behind closed doors following the Coronavirus outbreak. Both goals came from two errors by defender Raphael Varane due to City's high pressing of which Jesus played in an important role in
column7: sealing Manchester City's spot in the quarter finals. He was the only player to score in two separate games against Real Madrid in the 2019–2020 football season
column8: having also scored in the first leg in Madrid. This meant he reached 14 goals in only 22 Champions League games
column9: a record bettered by only three non-European players.

column1: Jesus was part of the Brazil under-20 team that finished as runners-up at the 2015 U-20 World Cup in New Zealand. He scored their first goal of the tournament in a 4–2 win over Nigeria in New Plymouth
column2: and converted as they advanced past Uruguay and Portugal on penalties.
he was chosen in Dunga's provisional 40-man squad for the Copa América Centenario in the United States
column3: and was considered as a replacement for the injured Douglas Costa in the final selection but missed out through the lack of a U.S. visa. Later that year
column4: he was one of five forwards named in the squad for the team's hosting of the Olympic tournament. He scored once against Danish keeper Jeppe Højbjerg in their final group game against Denmark
column6: and in the semi-final against Honduras he added two more in a 6–0 victory. Jesus won the Olympics with his team against Germany in a penalty shootout
column7: scoring one of the penalties.Jesus made his debut for the senior team on 1 September 2016
column8: in a 2018 FIFA World Cup qualification game against Ecuador in Quito. He started the match and scored twice
column9: as Brazil won 3–0. Jesus was Brazil's highest scorer in the CONMEBOL World Cup qualifiers

column2: he was named in Tite's final 23-man squad for the 2018 FIFA World Cup in Russia. Jesus started all five games for Brazil at the tournament without scoring a goal.In May 2019
column3: Jesus was included in Brazil's 23-man squad for the 2019 Copa América on home soil. In the final against Peru on 7 July
column5: he assisted the opening goal scored by Everton Soares
column6: and later scored the match-winning goal late in the first half; however
column7: he was sent off in the second half after collecting a second yellow card during the final following a collision with Carlos Zambrano. Brazil won the match 3–1 to win the title. In August 2019
column8: Jesus was handed a 2-month international ban from CONMEBOL
column9: due to his behavior after being red carded in the 2019 Copa América Final.

column2: Jesus is capable of playing in several attacking positions: he has been deployed as a centre forward
column6: as a winger or as an attacking midfielder
column7: and is renowned for his pace
column13: and work ethic. Former Brazilian striker Ronaldo has praised Jesus and touted him for future success with the Brazilian national team.In October 2019
column14: Jesus said he was open to switching to a winger role at Manchester City in the hope of getting more playing time
column15: though he acknowledged that there was still intense competition in the team for a starting spot out on the wing.

column1: Gabriel Jesus came to England with his mother and older brother along with two friends. He comes from a religious family and reportedly chose to wear the number 33 in tribute to the age at which Jesus Christ is believed to have been crucified. He and Neymar got matching tattoos in August 2016 depicting a boy overlooking a favela.
